content: The "Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2007" allows accident and health plans to apply to eligible beneficiaries. The Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2007 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries and qualifying children who are dependents. It also excludes amounts expended for medical care. The Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2007 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide coverage for eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and their dependents for amounts expended on medical care. It also includes provisions for payroll taxes related to eligible beneficiaries and their qualifying children. The Tax Equity for Health Plan Beneficiaries Act of 2007 expands coverage under the Internal Revenue Code to include eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and their dependents for medical care expenses. Amendments are made to sections 3231(e)(1) and 3306(b)(2) to specify the inclusion of eligible beneficiaries and qualifying children in payroll tax provisions. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include expanding coverage to eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and their dependents for medical care expenses. Changes are made to sections 3306(b)(2) and 3401(a) to specify the inclusion of eligible beneficiaries and qualifying children in payroll tax provisions. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code expand coverage to eligible beneficiaries, qualifying children, and their dependents for medical care expenses. Changes are made to payroll tax provisions for any payment made to an employee or their eligible beneficiary, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. Expansion of dependency for health insurance deduction for self-employed individuals. Expansion of dependency for health insurance deduction for self-employed individuals. The amendment includes new criteria for dependents, expanding the definition to cover individuals who meet specific requirements outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment expands the definition of dependents for the health insurance deduction for self-employed individuals, with new criteria outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4. Extension to eligible beneficiaries of sick and accident benefits provided to members of a voluntary employees' beneficiary association and their dependents. The amendment expands the definition of dependents for the health insurance deduction for self-employed individuals, with new criteria outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. Effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. SEC. 5. Flexible spending arrangements and health reimbursement arrangements. The Secretary of Treasury will issue guidance allowing medical expenses eligible for reimbursement from flexible spending arrangements and health reimbursement arrangements to be reimbursed, even if they are for individuals who are not spouses or dependents. Employees can designate individuals who are not spouses or dependents to have their medical expenses reimbursed under the health reimbursement arrangement.
